components.data:
Clone the 'metagenomics-book' repo if necessary (NOT in your own 'abe487' repo):

 

  $ git clone https://github.com/kyclark/metagenomics-book.git

 

Then pull to get the latest code and copy the 'problems/greeting' directory into your '~/abe487/problems' (assuming your repo is located in your $HOME):

 

  $ cd metagenomics-book

  $ git pull

  $ cp -r problems/greeting ~/abe487/problems

  $ cd !$

  $ git add greeting

  $ git commit -m 'new homework' greeting
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Clone the 'metagenomics-book' repo if necessary (NOT in your own 'abe487' repo):

 

  $ git clone https://github.com/kyclark/metagenomics-book.git

 

Then pull to get the latest code and copy the 'problems/greeting' directory into your '~/abe487/problems' (assuming your repo is located in your $HOME):

 

  $ cd metagenomics-book

  $ git pull

  $ cp -r problems/greeting ~/abe487/problems

  $ cd !$

  $ git add greeting

  $ git commit -m 'new homework' greeting

components.data:
Edit the existing 'greeting.pl6' file to take a single, positional (not named) argument called 'name.'  If you type 'make,' it will execute the script with $USER like so:

 

$ make
./greeting.pl6 kyclark
Hello, kyclark, your name has 7 characters.

$ ./greeting.pl6 'John Coltrane'
Hello, John Coltrane, your name has 13 characters.

 

The argument you are getting from the command line is a string, so you will want to read the docs on the "Str" type:

 

https://docs.perl6.org/type/Str

 

If your program is given no arguments, it should print a "usage" statement.  If you use the "MAIN" subroutine with a proper signature, this will happen automatically; otherwise, you will need to handle this yourself.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Edit the existing 'greeting.pl6' file to take a single, positional (not named) argument called 'name.'  If you type 'make,' it will execute the script with $USER like so:

 

$ make
./greeting.pl6 kyclark
Hello, kyclark, your name has 7 characters.

$ ./greeting.pl6 'John Coltrane'
Hello, John Coltrane, your name has 13 characters.

 

The argument you are getting from the command line is a string, so you will want to read the docs on the "Str" type:

 

https://docs.perl6.org/type/Str

 

If your program is given no arguments, it should print a "usage" statement.  If you use the "MAIN" subroutine with a proper signature, this will happen automatically; otherwise, you will need to handle this yourself.

components.data:
Your solution is correct when "make test" looks like this:

 

$ make test
./test.pl6
ok 1 - No args gives usage
ok 2 - Correct output

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 3 of C_HW3 (Hello, Perl)
source_data.annotation: I didn't make a usage for this assignment but I managed to pass both tests. How is this possible? (Is this related to my specification of Str?)
source_data.thread_text: I didn't make a usage for this assignment but I managed to pass both tests. How is this possible? (Is this related to my specification of Str?)
source_data.body: I didn't make a usage for this assignment but I managed to pass both tests. How is this possible? (Is this related to my specification of Str?)

comments.name: James Thornton Jr
comments.comment_text: Yep! Perl 6 will make a usage statement for you.
comments.body: Yep! Perl 6 will make a usage statement for you.

components.data:
Commit and push your work to Github for checking:

 

  $ git commit -m 'works now' greeting.pl6

  $ git push
